name: Southern Screamer
description: A robust bird with overall gray plumage and a dark collar around its neck. A distinctive feature of all three screamer species is the horn-covered spurs on the wing bends, used for defense against enemies.
image_alt: Southern screamer, photo: Prague Zoo Archive
proportions: Body length 61–69 cm; tail length 22–26 cm; wing length 53–57 cm; weight 4–4.5 kg
attractions: Screamers are sturdy birds closely related to ducks and geese. They are excellent swimmers and capable fliers. The southern screamer lives in small flocks, communicating with loud calls. This is especially noticeable in the evening when they circle over water, shrieking piercingly. They build a massive nest on the shore or in wetlands, with both parents tending to egg incubation and chick care.
breeding: Prague Zoo has kept screamers since 1954, achieving their first breeding in 1984—the third zoo in Europe to do so.
